G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3, as this action arises from a residential tenancy within Suffolk County.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord is prohibited from interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Inspectional Services inspected the Premises and found code violations related to the water intrusion and other deficiencies in violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a718.proposition: Defendant asserted that the nonrenewal was related to the late rent payment but, in fact, it appears to be retaliation for Plaintiff’s lawful complaint to city inspectors under G.L. c. 186, §18.

105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.750, and 410.800.proposition: The sustained water intrusion, dampness, and resulting unsanitary conditions violate the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.750, and 410.800, rendering the dwelling unfit for human habitation and constituting an interference prohibited by law.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of leased property—including persistent water leaks and code violations—constitutes a breach of this covenant.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes that recurring, substantial flooding and unsanitary conditions in a leased apartment, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, constitute both a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court affirms liability and damages based on repeated flooding that impaired the character and value of the premises, expressly tying the landlord’s statutory and common-law quiet enjoyment obligations to maintaining watertight, sanitary conditions. This directly supports the proposition that substantial interference with use and enjoyment through persistent leaks and code violations breaches the covenant.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition… At a minimum, this warranty imposes on the landlord a duty to keep the dwelling in conformity with the State Sanitary Code… Further, a landlord that fails to maintain a habitable dwelling for its tenant is liable for resulting personal injuries… Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code… provides that apartments must be watertight… Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of leased property—including persistent water leaks and code violations—constitutes a breach of this covenant.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of leased premises can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the interference here is excessive noise from a bar, not water leaks or building/code violations. The court’s reasoning focuses on landlord responsibility for noise and nuisance created by a commercial tenant and control over those conditions. It does not discuss water intrusion, housing code violations, or similar conditions, so citing it specifically for that aspect overstates its holding.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

Tracy v. Boss, 316 Mass. 256 (1944).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of leased property—including persistent water leaks and code violations—constitutes a breach of this covenant.
Tracy v. Boss, 316 Mass. 256 (1944).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a negligence action arising from an automobile accident involving a child on neighboring property. It does not involve a lease, landlord-tenant relationship, habitability issues, or any covenant of quiet enjoyment or related concept. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that substantial interference with use and enjoyment of leased premises through leaks or code violations constitutes a breach of such a covenant.
Tracy v. Boss, 316 Mass. 256 (1944).relevant_excerpt: We have stated all the evidence bearing upon negligence of the defendant. Without pausing to discuss the problems involved in finding that the plaintiff was more than a mere licensee on land of the defendant’s father... we are of opinion that even if the defendant owed to the plaintiff the duty to exercise ordinary care, the evidence would not warrant a finding that negligence on the part of the defendant caused the accident.

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the Premises in a habitable condition and to remedy the water infiltration despite repeated notice amounts to a “serious interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment as defined in Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: Doe defines “serious interference” with quiet enjoyment in the context of criminal drug activity and a landlord’s failure to take measures to remove unlawful actors from common areas. It does not address water infiltration, habitability defects, or physical conditions of the premises as constituting serious interference. In fact, the court expressly limits the warranty of habitability to physical defects and treats quiet enjoyment separately, so using Doe as authority that failure to remedy water infiltration constitutes serious interference misstates the holding.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons… then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: A landlord’s duty to provide habitable premises arises both under the common law and under the implied warranty of habitability, recognized in Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a concurrence/dissent, not the majority opinion, and the author explicitly disagrees with using an implied warranty of habitability as the doctrinal vehicle, preferring instead an implied agreement to comply with statutory and code standards. While he agrees the old common-law ‘no duty to repair’ rule should be reconsidered, he does not ground the landlord’s duty in a broad, judicially created implied warranty of habitability as the proposition states. Thus, this portion of Hemingway does not support the claim that the landlord’s duty arises both under common law and an implied warranty of habitability recognized in this case; it instead critiques that approach.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law. The court states the new rule to be that the landlord renting a dwelling unit impliedly warrants to the tenant ‘that the premises are fit for human occupation….’ I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule….”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s inaction following notice of the habitability defects demonstrates willful and knowing disregard of Plaintiff’s rights, warranting enhanced damages under G.L. c. 186, §14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion holds that liability under G.L. c. 186, §14 requires at least negligent conduct and that a statutory violation alone is insufficient; it does not address or apply the statute’s enhanced-damages ‘willful and knowing’ standard. The case focuses on whether strict liability under the lead paint statute automatically triggers §14 remedies (including attorneys’ fees) and concludes it does not, and therefore provides no authority that a landlord’s inaction after notice warrants enhanced damages for willful and knowing disregard of tenant rights.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”
